content: The UA MS in Software Engineering is a 30-credit masterâ€™s program administered by the Department of Systems & Industrial Engineering. It provides a firm engineering foundation via core graduate courses and lets students build a custom plan of study. The interdisciplinary curriculum is designed so that after core courses, students may choose electives and research aligned with domains such as web and mobile applications, artificial intelligence, cloud computing, embedded systems, cybersecurity, machine learning, and other interdisciplinary areas. The program can be completed via thesis or non-thesis track.
Core graduate-level courses in the MS program include SFWE 507 (Foundations of Software Engineering), SFWE 502 (Software DevSecOps), and SFWE 503 (Software Project Management).

After the core courses, students choose remaining coursework (electives and possibly research) so that their coursework and research path matches their chosen domain. This customization allows a student to specialize in areas such as cloud computing, AI, embedded systems, cybersecurity, or web/mobile software as desired. (As of 2025 catalog entry)
The MS program supports both thesis and non-thesis (coursework) options. Students may choose the format that best fits their career goals or schedule. ([UA Graduate Catalog SFEMS])

The MS Software Engineering program is offered online or via the Tucson campus, supporting students who are working or need flexible scheduling. This allows professionals to complete the degree part-time if needed. ([UA ECE / Engineering online offerings page])

The 30-credit MS consists of a small number of core courses and the remainder is electives or research, so students can tailor their degree to their strengths, career aspirations, or research interests. ([UA online MSSE program description])
